content.text: Describe the motion of the car from 0 to 50 s, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Describe the motion of the car from 50 s to 90 s, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Calculate the distance travelled by the car between 50 s and 90 s
distance travelled = .........m
The motorcycle travels \(710\mathrm{m}\) in \(87\mathrm{s}\)
Calculate the speed of the motorcycle and show that it is close to \(8\mathrm{m / s}\)
The motorcycle in part (b)(i) travels at a constant speed for 87 s
On Fig. 1.1, draw the speed–time graph for the motorcycle
A motorcycle travels at a constant speed
Fig. 1.1 shows a speed–time graph for a car
Calculate the weight of the mercury
weight of mercury = .........N
The \(12 \text{g}\) of mercury has a volume of \(0.88 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of mercury
density of mercury = .........\(g / cm^3\)
The mass of the mercury in the thermometer is \(12 \text{g}\)
State what happens to the mass of the mercury when its temperature rises
Tick \((\checkmark)\) one box
State what happens to the density of the mercury when its temperature rises
Tick \((\checkmark)\) one box
The mercury in the thermometer expands when its temperature rises
A liquid-in-glass thermometer contains mercury
A girl sits on one end of the plank, and her brother pushes down on the other end to make the plank balance horizontally. Fig. 3.1 shows the arrangement
Calculate the moment of the girl's weight about the pivot and show that it is close to \(480\mathrm{Nm}\)
The plank balances horizontally when the boy pushes down with a force \(F\) at a distance of \(1.6 \text{m}\) from the pivot
Calculate the size of force \(F\)
A plank balances horizontally on a log of wood, which acts as a pivot
Describe how the energy stored in the coal is used in a coal-fired power station to generate electrical energy
Some people in the country argue against building a new coal-fired power station
They say that the power station is expensive and not very efficient
Explain the meaning of not very efficient
Apart from cost and efficiency, give two other reasons for not building a coal-fired power station
A country needs to build new power stations to provide electricity for homes and industry
One type of power station is a coal-fired power station
Fig. 5.1 shows the horizontal forces acting on the suitcase
Calculate the resultant horizontal force on the suitcase
size of force = .........N
direction
After a short time, the suitcase is moving at a constant speed
Suggest values for the sizes of the two horizontal forces on the suitcase when it is moving at a constant speed
A man starts pulling his suitcase across the floor
The total downward force of the suitcase on the ground is \(150\mathrm{N}\). The suitcase has two wheels. Each wheel has an area of \(0.60\mathrm{cm}^2\) touching the ground
Calculate the pressure of the suitcase on the ground
pressure on the ground = .........N/cm²
State the term used for the motion of the smoke particle
Explain the motion of the smoke particle in Fig. 6.2
Fig. 6.1 shows a smoke cell. The smoke cell contains air molecules and smoke particles
A student views the motion of the smoke particles in the smoke cell by using a microscope
Fig. 6.2 shows the path of one of the smoke particles
Fig. 6.2
The rays leaving the prism represent the seven main colours of the visible spectrum
Complete the labelling on Fig. 7.1 by writing the colours of the visible spectrum in the table
the bending of the light as it enters the prism
the different amounts of bending that produce the spectrum
State the term used to describe:
A student incorrectly writes some sentences about electromagnetic waves. His teacher circles a mistake in each sentence
In the table, write a suitable correction for each mistake. The first one has been done for you

table.html:
student's sentencescorrection
the speed of light is faster than radio waves in a vacuumthe same as
X-rays are used in television remote controllers
radio waves have the highest frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum

content.text: A narrow beam of white light enters a glass prism and splits into the colours of the visible spectrum, as shown in Fig. 7.1
To increase the loudness of the sound, increase the ............................................ of the sound wave
To increase the pitch of the sound, increase the ............................................ of the sound wave
A loudspeaker is producing a sound
Choose words from the box to complete the sentences about sound
State the total distance the sound travels during the 0.56 s
distance = .........m
Calculate the speed of sound in air using the measurements given in part **(b)**
speed of sound = .........m/s
The students' value for the speed of sound is **not** accurate
Suggest **two** ways of improving the students' experiment
Two students determine the speed of sound in air
The students stand together, \(80 \text{m}\) from a large brick wall as shown in Fig. 8.1
One student shouts and as he shouts the other student starts a stop-watch. She stops the stop-watch when she hears the echo of the shout
The reading on the stop-watch is 0.56 s
State all materials that are electrical insulators
State one example of a magnetic material
The box lists four materials
Use words from the box to answer parts (i) and (ii)
Each word may be used once, more than once or not at all
Fig. 9.1 shows two magnets, P and Q, which are repelling each other
On magnet P, the N pole is labelled N
On Fig. 9.1, label the other pole on magnet P and **both** poles on magnet Q
One advantage that electromagnets have, compared with permanent magnets, is that their strength can easily be altered
State **one** other advantage of an electromagnet compared with a permanent magnet
A student wants to make the strongest electromagnet possible
Indicate which properties produce the **strongest** electromagnet
Tick \((\checkmark)\) one box in each list
**number of turns**
**in the coil**
**material in the core**
**size of current in the coil**
200 turns
air
20 mA
100 turns
iron
50 turns
plastic
Determine the combined resistance of the \(3.0 \Omega\) resistor and the \(5.0 \Omega\) lamp
combined resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
The reading on ammeter X is 0.50A
State the reading on ammeter Y
reading on ammeter Y = .........A
Fig. 10.1 shows a lamp and a resistor connected in a circuit
In another circuit, the \(3.0 \Omega\) resistor and the \(5.0 \Omega\) lamp are connected in parallel, as shown in Fig. 10.2
The lamp and resistor have changed from a series to a parallel combination
State and explain the effect of this change on the current in ammeter X
The current in a different lamp is 0.40A when the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp is 6.0V
Calculate the resistance of the lamp
resistance of lamp = .........\(\Omega\)
The student pulls the magnet through the coil to X and then releases it. The magnet moves up and down through the coil
State the type of voltage induced in the coil. Tick \((\checkmark)\) one box
State two ways of increasing the voltage induced in the coil
A student uses a coil and a magnet on a spring to generate an electromotive force (e.m.f.) that varies. He suspends the magnet above a coil as shown in Fig. 11.1
State which **two** nuclides have the same number of protons
State which **two** nuclides have the same number of nucleons
State which **one** of the four nuclides has the most electrons orbiting when it is in a neutral atom
Table 12.1 describes four nuclides

table.html:
name of nuclideplutonium-238thorium-234uranium-235uranium-238
nuclide notation238
94 Pu		234
90 Th		235
92 U		238
92 U

content.text: Thorium-234 has a half-life of 24 days. A sample of radioactive material contains \(40\mathrm{mg}\) of thorium-234
Calculate the mass of thorium-234 remaining after 72 days
mass of thorium-234 remaining = .........mg
